Trawler

Cost: 30 shields
Upkeep: 1 Gold
Moves: 9
Vision: 2.00 tiles
Attack: 0
Defense: 1
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 15
Obsolete by: None
Trawlers are high-powered work-boats used for fishing and ocean work. They work at the same rate as Workers, and can put down Buoys, Sea Bridges, Road types, or clean Pollution and Fallout. With Refrigeration, they can put down Fishtraps. Trawlers can carry one Land unit.

Trawlers can tow ships who haven‚Äôt moved, via a Load, Board, or Embark order. Towing helps damaged ships return to port for repair. Crew repair rates for towed ships are improved by letting the ships rest while towed.

When towing, encumbrance slows the Trawler to 6 move points. Remaining moves reduce proportional to this slower speed. If a Trawler stops towing a ship via Unload or Deboard, it regains pro-rated moves proportional to its natural speed. Towed ships lose all moves after release.

Everyone can see a Trawler‚Äôs cargo.

üîπ Multislot: can use additional city build slots.

‚û§ Belongs to RiverShip unit class.
  ‚Ä¢ Crew Repair: Automatically repairs +3 hitpoints each turn, regardless of movement.
  ‚Ä¢ Speed is not affected by terrain.
  ‚Ä¢ Does not get defense bonuses from terrain.
  ‚Ä¢ Slowed down while damaged.
‚û§ RESTRICTED by Zones of Control.
‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't prevent enemy cities from working the tile it's on.
‚û§ A non-military unit:
  ‚Ä¢ Cannot attack.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't impose martial law.
  ‚Ä¢ Can enter foreign territory regardless of peace treaty.
  ‚Ä¢ Never provokes an auto-attack
‚û§ Can build some types of infrastructure.
  ‚Ä¢ Can build Quay, Road, Railroad, Maglev, Sea Bridge, and Canal on tiles.
  ‚Ä¢ Can build Buoy.
  ‚Ä¢ Can build Fishtrap.
    * must be adjacent to a Fish resource
    * must NOT be cardinally adjacent to another Fishtrap
‚û§ Can clean Pollution or Fallout from river tiles.
‚û§ Can carry and refuel 1 Trireme, Rivership, Sea, Land, LandNoKill, LandAirSea, LandRoad unit, Big Land, or commerce cargo unit.
  ‚Ä¢ Cargo is visible to all nations who can see the Trawler.
‚û§ Can "tow" a ship or submarine as cargo.
  ‚Ä¢ Can't tow other Trawlers.
  ‚Ä¢ Towing reduces the remaining percentage of move points proportional to a move speed of 6 move points per turn.
  ‚Ä¢ Pro-rated move points for the speed of 9 move points are proportionally recovered when a towed ship is released.
  ‚Ä¢ Towed ships are visible to all nations who can see the Trawler.
  ‚Ä¢ Towed ships lose all moves after unload, deboard, or disembark.
  ‚Ä¢ Towed ships who take no action during the turn will experience 10% crew repair and 10% resting repair for a total of 20% repair.
‚û§ PORT PENALTY: If attacked in a city, firepower is set to 1 and firepower of attacker is doubled.
‚û§ Capturable: can be captured on rivers, if conditions allow it.
‚û§ Expellable: can be expelled from rivers located on foreign tiles.
‚û§ Can never become veteran.

Cargo ships are Commerce units: they can establish Trade Routes and help build Wonders. They can travel rivers and oceans. Cargo ships can also carry four land units: thus, they are useful for transporting units by river or sea.

Transport

Cost: 50 shields
Upkeep: 1 Shield
Moves: 11
Vision: 3.46 tiles
Attack: 0
Defense: 3
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 30
Obsolete by: None
The Transport cannot attack but can defend itself when under attack. Marines can directly attack from a Transport. Its large cargo capacity makes it a significant logistical upgrade for sea transportation. The Transport is considered a military vessel: unwelcome in the waters of nations with whom you are at Peace. Transports do not cause unhappiness.

The Ironclad is an armored ship that is much more sturdy than the Frigate but loses transport capability and the ability to navigate rivers. From the Ironclad onward, warships are excellent at attacking shore targets, and can also pillage buoys.

Ironclads and all modern ships can Stack-EscapeÔºö60% odds to evade stack-death if attacker doesn‚Äôt have more moves than it does.

The Battleship is the supreme naval unit, with excellent offensive and defensive strength. It has a 2√ó defense bonus vs Submarines. No unit can stop this unit from attacking surface units on a tile.
Battleships may expend 5 move points to do a 3 round bombardment which hits up to 4 units within a stack, of which a maximum of one can be killed. This can be done on any units within 2 tiles distance. Defending Battleships get a free bombardment against Special Unit Attacks.

Submarine

Cost: 50 shields
Upkeep: 1 Shield, 1 Unhappy
Moves: 11
Vision: 3.46 tiles
Attack: 12
Defense: 2
Firepower: 2
Hitpoints: 28
Obsolete by: Missile Submarine
Submarines are strong attackers but weak defenders. They are unreachable by Air units, but do not block air attacks on surface ships. Submarines can‚Äôt attack units on shore.

Submarines can‚Äôt be seen by other players unless they haveÔºöa buoy cardinally adjacent, an Air unit or city adjacent, a Destroyer or more modern naval unit adjacent, a naval base adjacent or cardinally 2 tiles distant, or a helicopter 2 tiles distant. See the chart in Help >> Units >> Submarine.

Submarines have superior attrition rates when attacking in numbers. Attacks cost no move points (except those incurred by taking damage.) They excel at hit-and-run against weaker ships. They have a minimum speed of 5 when damaged.

‚û§ STACK ESCAPE: 75% odds to escape if stack defender loses, if attacker doesn‚Äôt have more moves than it does.

Missile Submarines are unreachable by Air units, but don‚Äôt block air attacks on surface ships.

Attacks cost no move points (except those incurred by taking damage.) Minimum speed is 5, when damaged.

‚û§ PORT PENALTY: If attacked in a city, firepower is set to 1 and firepower of attacker is doubled.
‚û§ Can attack against Submarine units, which are usually not reachable.
‚û§ Can attack against Helicopter units, which are usually not reachable.
‚û§ Attacking with fractional move points gives fractional attack power.
‚û§ Can Pillage
‚û§ May acquire veteran status.
  ‚Ä¢ Veterans have increased strength in combat.

Anti-Ballistic Missile

Cost: 35 shields
Upkeep: 0
Moves: 24
Vision: 1.41 tiles
Attack: 1
Defense: 0
Firepower: 10
Hitpoints: 1
Obsolete by: None
ABMs intercept enemy missiles. Because there is seldom enough time to order a launch against incoming missiles, ABMs are usually set to Vigil, which makes them automatically intercept adjacent offensive missiles (not other ABMs).
In the case of a missile trying non-adjacent nuclear detonation, each ABM on vigil has a 29% chance to intercept it within a 5x5 area of effect (minus the corners).
ABMs are useful for anti-missile defense outside of cities. They must be cargo on a Mobile SAM or similar missile-capable unit, and set to Vigil. ABMs aren't very effective against non-missiles. As a defensive unit, they cause no unhappiness. After required tech is known, 1 ABM is delivered free to each newly built unit capable of carrying missilies.
Multi-slot: Under certain conditions, cities can make one (or more) multi-slot units per turn, plus one of any other type.

MISSILES are meant to strike just after launch. If left in air, they can be killed.

Attack odds vs. different missiles are at the bottom.

*** Logistical Rules for ALL MissilesÔºö
The only way to transport a Missile is by: 1) ending its turn in a city, or 2) Airlift, or 3) as cargo on a transporter unit. To load a Missile as cargo, it must be in a city or a base.

üîπ Multislot: can use additional city build slots.

‚û§ Belongs to Missile unit class.
  ‚Ä¢ Speed is not affected by terrain.
  ‚Ä¢ Does not get defense bonuses from terrain.
  ‚Ä¢ Unreachable. Cannot be attacked except by Fighter types, Mobile SAM, AEGIS Cruiser, and nuclear weapons.
  ‚ó¶ Doesn't prevent enemy units from attacking other units on its tile.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't prevent enemy cities from working the tile it's on.
  ‚Ä¢ AIRLIFT: Can be airlifted if it has remaining moves.
‚û§ Unblockable: unreachable units can't block its attacks on reachable units.
‚û§ VIGIL: can be given the Vigil order to intercept adjacent enemy missiles.
  ‚Ä¢ Prevents Nuclear Attack from missiles.
    ‚Ä¢ Detonation must be within 21-tile area of effect (5x5 minus 4 corners).
    ‚Ä¢ 29.3% chance of success for each ABM within distance.
    ‚Ä¢ ABM must be set to Vigil.
‚û§ Largely ineffective against non-Missile units.
‚û§ Unable to attack air units.
‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
‚û§ Unit must be in a City, Airbase, Mobile SAM, Missile Destroyer, AEGIS Cruiser, Missile Submarine, or Carrier type after 1 turn.
‚û§ Can Attack
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Anti-Ballistic Missile.
‚û§ Can't be bribed.
‚û§ Can't be sabotaged.
‚û§ No Home City: not susceptible to upkeep nor disbanding.
‚û§ May be built with veteran status.
  ‚Ä¢ Must be built in a city with Airport.
  ‚Ä¢ Veterans have increased strength in combat.
Attack Odds for Anti-Ballistic Missiles:

Cruise Missile

Cost: 60 shields
Upkeep: 1 Shield, 1 Unhappy
Moves: 24
Vision: 1.41 tiles
Attack: 18
Defense: 0
Firepower: 3
Hitpoints: 10
Obsolete by: None
A Cruise Missile can strike distant targets. It cannot attack Air units, but Air units never block a strike on reachable surface units. Cruise Missiles can be relocated by ending their turn on a city, airbase, Missile Destroyer, AEGIS Cruiser, Missile Submarine, Carrier type, or Mobile SAM. A Cruise Missile cannot block attacks on other units on its tile.
Via the Pillage commmand, a Cruise Missile has a 60% chance to strike and destroy a tile improvement. You may select the target with the Do command, then select Tile Target.

MISSILES are meant to strike just after launch. If left in air, they can be killed.


*** Logistical Rules for ALL MissilesÔºö
The only way to transport a Missile is by: 1) ending its turn in a city, or 2) Airlift, or 3) as cargo on a transporter unit. To load a Missile as cargo, it must be in a city or a base.

‚û§ Belongs to Missile unit class.
  ‚Ä¢ Speed is not affected by terrain.
  ‚Ä¢ Does not get defense bonuses from terrain.
  ‚Ä¢ Unreachable. Cannot be attacked except by Fighter types, Mobile SAM, AEGIS Cruiser, and nuclear weapons.
  ‚ó¶ Doesn't prevent enemy units from attacking other units on its tile.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't prevent enemy cities from working the tile it's on.
  ‚Ä¢ AIRLIFT: Can be airlifted if it has remaining moves.
‚û§ Unblockable: unreachable units can't block its attacks on reachable units.
‚û§ Can safely iPillage: Instant Missile Strike against tile infrastructure.
  ‚Ä¢ 60% odds of success. +5% for each veteran level.
  ‚Ä¢ Destroys 1 selected infrastructural improvement on the tile, instantly.
  ‚Ä¢ Spends the unit.
‚û§ AEGIS and Armor II have a defense bonus against this unit.
‚û§ Unable to attack air units.
‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
‚û§ Can attack against Helicopter units, which are usually not reachable.
‚û§ Unit must be in a City, Airbase, Mobile SAM, Missile Destroyer, AEGIS Cruiser, Missile Submarine, or Carrier type after 1 turn.
‚û§ Can Attack
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Cruise Missile.
‚û§ Can't be bribed.
‚û§ Can't be sabotaged.
‚û§ May be built with veteran status.
  ‚Ä¢ Must be built in a city with Airport.
  ‚Ä¢ Veterans have increased strength in combat.

Nuclear Missile

Cost: 160 shields
Upkeep: 1 Shield, 1 Unhappy
Moves: 24
Vision: 1.41 tiles
Attack: 100
Defense: 0
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 10
Obsolete by: None
If you have Space Flight and the Manhattan Project has been built by any player, you can make Nuclear Missiles. Nuclear blasts affect all units in a 3√ó3 area, and up to 2 tile improvements on each tile (√ó2 at ground zero). City population is reduced by 45%. Land tiles may get nuclear fallout. Fallout reduces tile output and increases risk of nuclear winter. 
If Fallout is cleaned on the turn it appears, the chance of nuclear winter is reduced.

MISSILES are meant to strike just after launch. If left in air, they can be killed.


*** Logistical Rules for ALL MissilesÔºö
The only way to transport a Missile is by: 1) ending its turn in a city, or 2) Airlift, or 3) as cargo on a transporter unit. To load a Missile as cargo, it must be in a city or a base.

‚û§ Belongs to Missile unit class.
  ‚Ä¢ Speed is not affected by terrain.
  ‚Ä¢ Does not get defense bonuses from terrain.
  ‚Ä¢ Unreachable. Cannot be attacked except by Fighter types, Mobile SAM, AEGIS Cruiser, and nuclear weapons.
  ‚ó¶ Doesn't prevent enemy units from attacking other units on its tile.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't prevent enemy cities from working the tile it's on.
  ‚Ä¢ AIRLIFT: Can be airlifted if it has remaining moves.
‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
‚û§ Unblockable: unreachable units can't block its attacks on reachable units.
‚û§ Can perform a Nuclear Detonation obliterating all adjacent tiles.
‚û§ Field unit: one unhappiness applies even when non-aggressive.
‚û§ Unit must be in a City, Airbase, Mobile SAM, Missile Destroyer, AEGIS Cruiser, Missile Submarine, or Carrier type after 1 turn.
‚û§ Can Explode Nuclear
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Nuclear Missile.
‚û§ Can Attack
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Nuclear Missile.
  ‚Ä¢ causes Nuclear Detonation centered on the target tile.
  ‚Ä¢ creates International Outrage: all nations have casus belli.
‚û§ Can't be bribed.
‚û§ Can't be sabotaged.
‚û§ Can never become veteran.

Tactical Nuke

Cost: 140 shields
Upkeep: 1 Shield, 1 Unhappy
Moves: 18
Vision: 1.41 tiles
Attack: 100
Defense: 0
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 10
Obsolete by: None
Tactical Nukes are very small warheads attached to missiles. A Tactical Nuke affects all units on a single tile, and up to 4 tile improvements. City population is reduced by 45%. The target tile may get Fallout. In theory, Tactical Nukes are small enough to get the advantages of nuclear armaments without the severity of consequences. In reality, they might be a gateway that escalates toward mutual assured destruction.
If you have Fusion Power and the Manhattan Project was built, a Tactical Nuke can be made in a city with an Enrichment Facility.

MISSILES are meant to strike just after launch. If left in air, they can be killed.


*** Logistical Rules for ALL MissilesÔºö
The only way to transport a Missile is by: 1) ending its turn in a city, or 2) Airlift, or 3) as cargo on a transporter unit. To load a Missile as cargo, it must be in a city or a base.

‚û§ Belongs to Missile unit class.
  ‚Ä¢ Speed is not affected by terrain.
  ‚Ä¢ Does not get defense bonuses from terrain.
  ‚Ä¢ Unreachable. Cannot be attacked except by Fighter types, Mobile SAM, AEGIS Cruiser, and nuclear weapons.
  ‚ó¶ Doesn't prevent enemy units from attacking other units on its tile.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't prevent enemy cities from working the tile it's on.
  ‚Ä¢ AIRLIFT: Can be airlifted if it has remaining moves.
‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
‚û§ Can only be built if there is Enrichment Facility in the city.
‚û§ Unblockable: unreachable units can't block its attacks on reachable units.
‚û§ Can perform a Nuclear Detonation obliterating only the targeted tile.
‚û§ Field unit: unhappiness applies even when non-aggressive.
‚û§ Unit must be in a City, Airbase, Mobile SAM, Missile Destroyer, AEGIS Cruiser, Missile Submarine, or Carrier type after 1 turn.
‚û§ Can Explode Nuclear
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Tactical Nuke.
‚û§ Can Attack
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Tactical Nuke.
  ‚Ä¢ causes Nuclear Detonation only on the target tile.
  ‚Ä¢ creates International Outrage: all nations have casus belli.
‚û§ Can't be bribed.
‚û§ Can't be sabotaged.
‚û§ Can never become veteran.

Bombs

Cost: 25 shields
Upkeep: 0
Moves: 1
Vision: 0.00 tiles
Attack: 10
Defense: 0
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 10
Obsolete by: None
While bombers carry standard weaponry included, the Bombs unit represents an extra payload of target-degrading weaponry. This lets bombers disrupt target defenses before coming in for a riskier fatal strike. Only bombers with high capacity can carry this unit.
Bombs can only be moved by bombers, trains, or the airlift order. They can‚Äôt attack from inside a domestic city. Bombs are cheap, but they damage more often than kill, and even victory has a cost. Hidden expenses lie in logistics, delivery risk, and non-reusability.

üîπ Multislot: can use additional city build slots.

‚û§ Belongs to Bomb unit class.
  ‚Ä¢ Speed is not affected by terrain.
  ‚Ä¢ Unreachable. Most units cannot attack this one.
    ‚ó¶ Doesn't prevent enemy units from attacking other units on its tile.
  ‚Ä¢ AIRLIFT: Can be airlifted if it has remaining moves.
‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
‚û§ Unit has to be in a city, an Airbase, or on a Medium Bomber, Heavy Bomber, Strategic Bomber, Jet Bomber, or Stealth Bomber after 1 turn.
‚û§ Can Explode
  ‚Ä¢ Must be done while carried by a bomber-type while not inside a friendly city.
  ‚Ä¢ Uses up the Bombs.
  ‚Ä¢ Unable to attack air units.
‚û§ Can't be bribed.
‚û§ Can't be sabotaged.
‚û§ No Home City: not susceptible to upkeep nor disbanding.
‚û§ Can never become veteran.

Atom Bomb

Cost: 150 shields
Upkeep: 1 Shield, 1 Unhappy
Moves: 2
Vision: 0.00 tiles
Attack: 100
Defense: 0
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 10
Obsolete by: None
If you have Nuclear Fission and the Manhattan Project has been built by any player, you can make Atom Bombs. A Bomber can drop it within two tiles of its location. Disembark the bomb and fly the Bomber out of range, then attack the target (or detonate by pressing D twice.) The blast affects ALL cardinally adjacent tiles, and may destroy a tile improvement on each tile (√ó2 at ground zero). City population is reduced by 35%. Land tiles may get nuclear fallout. 
Fallout reduces tile output and increases risk of nuclear winter.

  ‚Ä¢ AIRLIFT: Can be airlifted if it has remaining moves.
‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
‚û§ Unblockable: unreachable units can't block its attacks on reachable units.
‚û§ Can perform a Nuclear Detonation obliterating all cardinally adjacent tiles.
‚û§ Field unit: one unhappiness applies even when non-aggressive.
‚û§ Unit must be in a city, base, Train, Heavy Bomber, Strategic Bomber, Jet Bomber, or Stealth Bomber after 1 turn.

  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Atom Bomb.
‚û§ Can Attack
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Atom Bomb.

Hydrogen Bomb

Cost: 190 shields
Upkeep: 1 Shield, 2 Unhappy
Moves: 2
Vision: 0.00 tiles
Attack: 100
Defense: 0
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 10
Obsolete by: None
Hydrogen Bombs make Atom Bombs seem tame. Any unprotected city at Ground Zero will be absolutely annihilated. In other cities in the blast radius, population is reduced by 60%. Blast area is 21 tiles: the same area as an entire city (5√ó5 minus the corners.) All units within the blast are affected, and up to 3 tile improvements on each tile (√ó2 at ground zero).
A Bomber can drop a Hydrogen Bomb within two tiles of its location. Unload the bomb, fly the Bomber out of range, then detonate by pressing D twice.
If you have Fusion Power and the Manhattan Project was built, a Hydrogen Bomb can be made in a city with an Enrichment Facility. 
Fallout from a Hydrogen Bomb is grave, with more than double the contaminated area.

  ‚Ä¢ AIRLIFT: Can be airlifted if it has remaining moves.
‚û§ Can only be built if there is Enrichment Facility in the city.
‚û§ Unblockable: unreachable units can't block its attacks on reachable units.
‚û§ Can perform a Nuclear Detonation obliterating a 5√ó5 square minus the corners.
‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
‚û§ Field unit: unhappiness applies even when non-aggressive.
‚û§ Unit must be in a City, Airbase, Train, Heavy Bomber, Strategic Bomber, Jet Bomber, or Stealth Bomber after 1 turn.
‚û§ Can Explode Nuclear
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Hydrogen Bomb.

Doomsday Bomb

Cost: 1000 shields
Upkeep: 1 Shield, 4 Unhappy
Moves: 2
Vision: 0.00 tiles
Attack: 100
Defense: 0
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 30
Obsolete by: None
The Doomsday Bomb is the mother of all bombs. Blast area is about 100 tiles. Only one can be made at a time. A city at Ground Zero will be annihilated. Other cities in the blast area lose about 70% of their population! All units within the blast are affected, and up to 3 tile improvements on each tile (√ó2 at ground zero).
A Bomber can drop the Bomb within two tiles of its location. Unload the Bomb and pray that you can fly the Bomber out of range. Detonate by pressing D twice.
If you have Fusion Power and the Manhattan Project was built, a Doomsday Bomb can be made in a city with an Enrichment Facility. 
The Fallout from a Doomsday Bomb is a sure ticket to Nuclear Winter.

‚û§ Belongs to Bomb unit class.
  ‚Ä¢ Speed is not affected by terrain.
  ‚Ä¢ Unreachable. Most units cannot attack this one.
  ‚ó¶ Doesn't prevent enemy units from attacking other units on its tile.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't prevent enemy cities from working the tile it's on.
  ‚Ä¢ AIRLIFT: Can be airlifted if it has remaining moves.
‚û§ Can only be built if there is Enrichment Facility in the city.
‚û§ Unblockable: unreachable units can't block its attacks on reachable units.
‚û§ Each player may only have one of this type of unit.
‚û§ Can perform a Nuclear Detonation obliterating all tiles within a circle of diameter 11 tiles.
‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
‚û§ Field unit: unhappiness applies even when non-aggressive.
‚û§ Unit must be in a City, Airbase, Train, Heavy Bomber, Strategic Bomber, Jet Bomber, or Stealth Bomber after 1 turn.
‚û§ Can Explode Nuclear
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Doomsday Bomb.
  ‚Ä¢ target must be at the same tile.
‚û§ Can Attack
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Doomsday Bomb.
  ‚Ä¢ causes Nuclear Detonation centered on the target tile.
  ‚Ä¢ creates International Outrage: all nations have casus belli.
‚û§ Can't be bribed.
‚û§ Can't be sabotaged.
‚û§ Can never become veteran.

Emissary

Cost: 24 shields
Upkeep: 0
Moves: 3
Vision: 2.00 tiles
Attack: 0
Defense: 0
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 8
Obsolete by: Diplomat
An Emissary performs official or covert actions. Covert actions make incidents which let Senates break treaties. Emissaries in cities may defend such acts with diplomatic combat. Emissaries can
  ‚Ä¢ Bribe a lone unit
  ‚Ä¢ Establish embassy
  ‚Ä¢ Investigate City
  ‚Ä¢ Steal tech
  ‚Ä¢ Steal maps
  ‚Ä¢ Incite city revolt.

Except for Bribing and Investigate City, diplomatic actions will spend the Emissary, making him unavailable for further use.

Emissaries may claim a tile for your nation if adjacent to a tile claim made inside your own national border. Foreign tile claims require the Emissary to be accompanied by another unit.

Emissaries have no upgrade cost. Full rules for Emissaries are in the Manual.

‚û§ Belongs to Land unit class.
  ‚Ä¢ Slowed down while damaged.
  ‚Ä¢ AIRLIFT: Can be airlifted if it has remaining moves.
  ‚Ä¢ Can't do actions as Cargo. Must first unload.
‚û§ Defends cities against diplomatic actions.
‚û§ IGNORES Zones of Control.
‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't prevent enemy cities from working the tile it's on.
‚û§ IGNORES Zones of Control.
‚û§ A non-military unit:
  ‚Ä¢ Cannot attack.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't impose martial law.
  ‚Ä¢ Can enter foreign territory regardless of peace treaty.
  ‚Ä¢ Never provokes an auto-attack
‚û§ Can do Diplomatic Operations:
  ‚Ä¢ is done to foreign cities.
  * 'Become Ambassador'
      ¬∑ creates a permanent Embassy.
      ‚Ä¢ uses up the Emissary.
      ¬∑ can't be done at War if city is Theocratic or has Police Station.
      * getting caught before performing this action during Armistice, Cease-fire, or Peace gives the victim Casus Belli against you.
  * 'Investigate City' (does not spend the unit)
‚û§ Can do Hostile Diplomatic Operations:
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Emissary.
  ‚Ä¢ is done to foreign cities.
  ‚Ä¢ can lead to a diplomatic battle against a defender.
  * 'Steal Technology'
  * 'Incite a Revolt'
  * 'Steal Map Fragments'
‚û§ Can do Field Operations:
  ‚Ä¢ does not use up the Emissary.
  ‚Ä¢ is done to foreign individual units alone on a tile.
  * 'Bribe Enemy Unit' (does not spend the unit)
  * 'Tile Claim' - Claims sovereignty over a tile
    ¬∑ requires the tile be in domestic territory OR be adjacent to another tile claim.
    ‚Ä¢ in non-domestic territory, requires the actor be accompanied by a supporting unit.
‚û§ Can Upgrade
  ‚Ä¢ upgrades to Diplomat.
‚û§ Can Fortify. Only makes the Emissary stay put.
‚û§ Expellable: can be expelled from foreign tiles.
‚û§ May acquire veteran status.
  ‚Ä¢ Veterans have improved chances in diplomatic contests.

Diplomat

Cost: 30 shields
Upkeep: 0
Moves: 4
Vision: 2.00 tiles
Attack: 0
Defense: 0
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 8
Obsolete by: None
A Diplomat performs official or covert actions. Covert actions make incidents which let Senates break treaties. Diplomats can do what Emissaries can, and also:
  ‚Ä¢ Move faster
  ‚Ä¢ Establish Embassy without spending unit
  ‚Ä¢ Sabotage random production or buildings.

Except for Bribing, Establishing Embassy, and Investigate City, diplomatic actions will spend the Diplomat, making him unavailable for further use.

Diplomats may claim a tile for your nation if adjacent to a tile claim made inside your own national border. Foreign tile claims require the Diplomat to be accompanied by another unit.

Espionage tech allows Diplomats to establish hostile embassies vs. Courthouse and Homeland Security (but not vs. Police Station or Theocracy.)

Diplomats can be upgraded from Emissaries for free. Full rules for Diplomats are in the Manual.

  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't prevent enemy cities from working the tile it's on.
‚û§ Defends cities against diplomatic actions.

  ‚Ä¢ Cannot attack.

      * getting caught before performing this action during Armistice, Cease-fire, or Peace gives the victim Casus Belli against you.
  * 'Investigate City' (does not spend the unit)
‚û§ Can do Hostile Diplomatic Operations:
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Diplomat.

  * 'Steal Technology'

    ¬∑ requires the tile be in domestic territory OR be adjacent to another tile claim.

Spy

Cost: 35 shields
Upkeep: 0
Moves: 6
Vision: 2.83 tiles
Attack: 0
Defense: 0
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 8
Obsolete by: None
Except for establishing an embassy, Spies can do what a Diplomat can, and alsoÔºö
  ‚Ä¢ Survive ops (without being spent)
  ‚Ä¢ Sabotage lone units
  ‚Ä¢ Poison city water
  ‚Ä¢ Steal specific tech
  ‚Ä¢ Steal tech from cities more than once
  ‚Ä¢ Sabotage specific targets in cities.
  ‚Ä¢ Provide sentry intel even if not sentried.

Spies who survive ops escape to the nearest friendly city.

Spies have a 25% advantage over Diplomats in combatÔºöa base 75% chance to win.

Spies may claim a tile for your nation if adjacent to a tile claim made inside your own national border. Tile claims require the Spy to be accompanied by another unit. Full rules are in the Manual.

üîπ Multislot: can use additional city build slots.

  ‚Ä¢ Slowed down while damaged.

‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't prevent enemy cities from working the tile it's on.
‚û§ Strong in diplomatic battles.
‚û§ Defends cities against diplomatic actions.
‚û§ IGNORES Zones of Control.
‚û§ A non-military unit:
  ‚Ä¢ Cannot attack.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't impose martial law.
  ‚Ä¢ Can enter foreign territory regardless of peace treaty.
  ‚Ä¢ Never provokes an auto-attack

  ‚Ä¢ is done to foreign cities.

      ¬∑ can be done while Spy is transported cargo, using the 'D' (Do) command.

  ‚Ä¢ is done to foreign cities.
  ‚Ä¢ does not spend the unit except where noted.
  ‚Ä¢ can lead to a diplomatic battle against a defender.

  * 'Targeted Sabotage'
  * 'Steal Technology and Escape'
  * 'Targeted Tech Theft'
  * 'Incite a Revolt and Escape'
  * 'Steal Map Fragments and Escape'
  * 'Steal Map Fragments'
      ¬∑ uses up the Spy.
‚û§ Can do Field Operations:
  ‚Ä¢ is done to foreign individual units alone on a tile.
  * 'Bribe Enemy Unit'
  * 'Sabotage Enemy Unit'
      ¬∑ reduces target's hit points by half.
  * 'Tile Claim' - Claims sovereignty over a tile
    ¬∑ requires the tile be in domestic territory OR be adjacent to another tile claim.
    ‚Ä¢ in non-domestic territory, requires the actor be accompanied by a supporting unit.
‚û§ Can Pillage
‚û§ Can Fortify.  Only makes the Spy stay put.
‚û§ Expellable: can be expelled from foreign tiles.
‚û§ Can Sentry Always
  ‚Ä¢ Provides sentry intel of foreign unit movements even when not sentried.
‚û§ May acquire veteran status.
  ‚Ä¢ Veterans have improved chances in diplomatic contests.
  ‚Ä¢ Veterans are more likely to survive missions.

Patriarch

Cost: 55 shields
Upkeep: 0
Moves: 4
Vision: 2.00 tiles
Attack: 0
Defense: 0
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 8
Obsolete by: None
The Patriarch is unique‚Äîyou can make only one, and only with Theocracy in a city with an Ecclesiastical Palace. He can do what Diplomats can do, with extra powers of persuasion. Under Theocracy, the Patriarch converts units to join your side at 1/3 the cost of a normal Bribe; and incites cities to become yours at one third the normal cost.
Diplomatic actions can all be done multiple times if successful. Other actions spend the Patriarch, allowing no further use. A Patriarch may claim a tile for your nation if adjacent to a tile claim made inside your own national border. Foreign tile claims require the Patriarch to be accompanied by another unit.
Espionage tech allows the Patriarch to establish hostile embassies vs. Courthouse and Homeland Security (but not vs. Police Station or Theocracy.)

In diplomatic contests, the wiles, power, and influence of the Patriarch make him equal to a Spy in strength.

‚û§ Belongs to Land unit class.
  ‚Ä¢ Slowed down while damaged.
  ‚Ä¢ AIRLIFT: Can be airlifted if it has remaining moves.
  ‚Ä¢ Can't do actions as Cargo. Must first unload.
‚û§ IGNORES Zones of Control.
‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't prevent enemy cities from working the tile it's on.
‚û§ Each player may only have one of this type of unit.
‚û§ Defends cities against diplomatic actions.
‚û§ A non-military unit:
  ‚Ä¢ Cannot attack.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't impose martial law.
  ‚Ä¢ Can enter foreign territory regardless of peace treaty.
  ‚Ä¢ Never provokes an auto-attack
‚û§ Can do Diplomatic Operations:
  ‚Ä¢ is done to foreign cities.
  * 'Establish Embassy' (does not spend the unit)
      ¬∑ creates a permanent Embassy.
      ¬∑ can't be done at War if city is Theocratic or has Police Station.
      * getting caught before performing this action during Armistice, Cease-fire, or Peace gives the victim Casus Belli against you.
  * 'Investigate City' (does not spend the unit)
‚û§ Can 'Incite a Revolt and Escape':
  ‚Ä¢ Is 1/3 the cost if done with Theocracy government.
  ‚Ä¢ does not spend the Patriarch.
  ‚Ä¢ is done to foreign cities.
  ‚Ä¢ can lead to a diplomatic battle against a defender.
‚û§ Can do Hostile Diplomatic Operations:
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Patriarch.
  ‚Ä¢ is done to foreign cities.
  ‚Ä¢ can lead to a diplomatic battle against a defender.
  * 'Sabotage City' selects random building or production.
  * 'Steal Technology'
  * 'Steal Map Fragments'
‚û§ Can do Field Operations:
  ‚Ä¢ does not use up the Patriarch.
  ‚Ä¢ is done to foreign individual units alone on a tile.
  * 'Convert Unit' (does not spend the unit)
    * Is 1/3 the cost of 'Bribe Enemy Unit' if done with Theocracy government.
  * 'Tile Claim' - Claims sovereignty over a tile
    ¬∑ requires the tile be in domestic territory OR be adjacent to another tile claim.
    ‚Ä¢ in non-domestic territory, requires the actor be accompanied by a supporting unit.
‚û§ Can Fortify. Only makes the Patriarch stay put.
‚û§ Expellable: can be expelled from foreign tiles.
‚û§ May acquire veteran status.
  ‚Ä¢ Veterans have improved chances in diplomatic contests.
  ‚Ä¢ Veterans are more likely to survive missions.

Wagon

Cost: 25 shields
Upkeep: 0
Moves: 3
Vision: 2.00 tiles
Attack: 0
Defense: 0
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 10
Obsolete by: Truck
Wagons are the first Commerce unit that can travel by land. Compared to a Caravan, they are defenseless. They must stay on roads and quays; or land bases. Wagons are useful for transporting slower units. Wagons have 3‚Öì move points, giving a range of 10 tiles on roads.

Wagons allow units with less than 3 move points to travel your roads faster. Any cargo can board a Wagon anywhere; but only Goods and Freight can embark. Passengers need a city, quay, or base to deboard. Cargo can disembark anywhere, but it uses up all move points. Everyone can see a Wagon‚Äôs cargo.
Read the help on Caravans to see what Commerce units can do.

‚û§ Belongs to LandRoad unit class.
  ‚Ä¢ Can only travel on roads.
‚û§ RESTRICTED by Zones of Control.
‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't prevent enemy cities from working the tile it's on.
‚û§ A non-military unit:
  ‚Ä¢ Cannot attack.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't impose martial law.
  ‚Ä¢ Can enter foreign territory regardless of peace treaty.
  ‚Ä¢ Never provokes an auto-attack
‚û§ Can carry up to 2 Foot soldiers, Goods, or Freight units.
  ‚Ä¢ Cargo can board outside a City.
  ‚Ä¢ Cargo can't embark. Must be on same tile to Board.
  ‚Ä¢ Cargo can disembark outside a City, and loses all moves.
  ‚Ä¢ Cargo cannot deboard outside a City, Quay, Fortress, or Naval Base.
  ‚Ä¢ Cargo is visible to all nations who can see the Wagon.
‚û§ Can Establish Trade Route
  ‚Ä¢ is done to foreign cities 15 or more tiles distant. (Manhattan Distance)
  ‚Ä¢ inactive during War.
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Wagon.
‚û§ Can Help Build Wonder
  ‚Ä¢ is done in friendly cities. Contributes the unit's shield cost to current production
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Wagon.
  ‚Ä¢ adds 25 production.
‚û§ Capturable: can be captured if conditions allow it.
‚û§ Expellable: can be expelled from foreign tiles.
‚û§ Can Upgrade
  ‚Ä¢ upgrades to Truck.
‚û§ Can never become veteran.

Caravan

Cost: 30 shields
Upkeep: 0
Moves: 2
Vision: 2.00 tiles
Attack: 0
Defense: 1
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 10
Obsolete by: Truck
The Caravan is versatile and rugged. It is the only all-terrain land Commerce unit. It is also the only one that presents no potential military threat to trade partners. It can defend itself, fortify, and carry 3 Goods or Freight.

Commerce units can help build Wonders in any city with whom you are not at war. They can create trade routes in foreign cities whose (Manhattan) distance is 15+ tiles. Trade routes increase net trade in both cities relative to their combined trade. Routes are inactive during war and (re)activate during peace.
Commerce units can build any Wonders for which you have the tech requirement. To use them for a Trade Route, they need to be given a Home City.
All Commerce units can carry Goods and Freight as cargo.

‚û§ Belongs to Land unit class.
  ‚Ä¢ Slowed down while damaged.
  ‚Ä¢ AIRLIFT: Can be airlifted if it has remaining moves.
‚û§ IGNORES Zones of Control.
‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't prevent enemy cities from working the tile it's on.
‚û§ A non-military unit:
  ‚Ä¢ Cannot attack.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't impose martial law.
  ‚Ä¢ Can enter foreign territory regardless of peace treaty.
  ‚Ä¢ Never provokes an auto-attack
‚û§ Can help build a Wonder in any non-hostile city.
‚û§ Can carry up to 3 Goods or Freight units.
  ‚Ä¢ Cargo not visible except to allies.
‚û§ Can Establish Trade Route
  ‚Ä¢ is done to foreign cities 15 or more tiles distant. (Manhattan Distance)
  ‚Ä¢ inactive during War.
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Caravan.
‚û§ Can Help Build Wonder
  ‚Ä¢ is done in friendly cities. Contributes the unit's shield cost to current production
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Caravan.
  ‚Ä¢ adds 30 production.
‚û§ Can Upgrade
  ‚Ä¢ upgrades to Truck.
‚û§ Can Fortify, granting a 50% defensive bonus when not in a city.
  ‚Ä¢ Gets the 50% defensive bonus automatically while in cities.
‚û§ Capturable: can be captured if conditions allow it.
‚û§ Expellable: can be expelled from foreign tiles.
‚û§ May acquire veteran status.
  ‚Ä¢ Veterans have increased strength in combat.

Train

Cost: 35 shields
Upkeep: 0
Range: 28 railed tiles
Vision: 2.00 tiles
Attack: 0
Defense: 1
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 30
Obsolete by: None
Trains are Commerce that allow you to carry Goods and Freight on your railways. They can carry any other land unit that has less than three move points. Logistics for Trains are more restricted than Wagons and Trucks. Except for Foot soldiers, all units need to be in a city to get on or off a Train.
Foot Soldiers use Trains the same as Wagons and Trucks, and can:
  1. Board anywhere (1/3 move);
  2. Deboard in a Base or Quay (1/3 move);
  3. Disembark outside a City (loses all moves.)

On non-allied foreign rails, Trains incur full terrain movement cost. Pre-gunpowder units can‚Äôt attack Trains.

Electricity and Combustion each give Trains the ability to travel +5 more tiles, resulting in a range of 33 and then 38 tiles.

üîπ Multislot: can use additional city build slots.

‚û§ Belongs to LandRail unit class.
  ‚Ä¢ Only able to move on railroad tiles.
  ‚Ä¢ Unreachable to pre-gunpowder units.
‚û§ RESTRICTED by Zones of Control.
‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't prevent enemy cities from working the tile it's on.
‚û§ A non-military unit:
  ‚Ä¢ Cannot attack.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't impose martial law.
  ‚Ä¢ Can enter foreign territory regardless of peace treaty.
  ‚Ä¢ Never provokes an auto-attack
‚û§ Can carry up to 6 qualifying units.
  ‚Ä¢ Units with less than 3 moves: e.g., Foot soldier, Ballistic class, Workers, Migrant types, Caravan, Freight, Goods, and Bomb units.
  ‚Ä¢ Can also carry and refuel Balloons and Zeppelins.
  ‚Ä¢ Some cargo cannot be loaded/unloaded except in a City.
  ‚Ä¢ Cargo not visible except to allies.
‚û§ Can Help Build Wonder
  ‚Ä¢ is done in friendly cities. Contributes the unit's shield cost to current production
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Train.
  ‚Ä¢ adds 35 production.
‚û§ Can Establish Trade Route
  ‚Ä¢ is done to foreign cities 15 or more tiles distant. (Manhattan Distance)
  ‚Ä¢ inactive during War.
  ‚Ä¢ uses up the Train.
‚û§ Capturable: can be captured if conditions allow it.
‚û§ Can never become veteran.

Truck

Cost: 50 shields
Upkeep: 0
Moves: 4
Vision: 2.00 tiles
Attack: 0
Defense: 1
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 20
Obsolete by: None
The Truck replaces the Caravan as the basic Commerce unit on Land. It moves at more than twice the speed; but is restricted to roads and quays, and can't use rails. Each Truck used to build a Wonder will add 50 shields. See the entry on Caravan to read what Commerce units may do.

Trucks allow units with less than 3 move points to travel your roads faster: Like the Wagon, any cargo can board a Truck anywhere, but a city, quay, or base is needed to deboard. Disembarking is legal for all cargo types, but uses up all moves (except Marines.)

üîπ Multislot: can use additional city build slots.

  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't impose martial law.
  ‚Ä¢ Can enter foreign territory regardless of peace treaty.
  ‚Ä¢ Never provokes an auto-attack
‚û§ Can carry up to 3 qualifying units: Foot Soldiers, Artillery, Workers, Caravan, Goods, and Freight units.
  ‚Ä¢ Cargo can't embark. Must be on same tile to Board.
  ‚Ä¢ Cargo can disembark outside a City, and loses all moves.
  ‚Ä¢ Cargo cannot deboard outside a City, Quay, or Base.
  ‚Ä¢ Cargo not visible except to allies.

Goods

Cost: 20 shields
Upkeep: 0
Moves: 1
Vision: 1.41 tiles
Attack: 0
Defense: 0
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 1
Obsolete by: Freight
Goods are used to establish Trade Routes, Help Build Wonders, and contribute to city production. Recycle Production has a penalty of only 3 shields, yielding 17 shields into a city‚Äôs production target.

Goods can only move to tiles with a City, Railroad, Quay, Fortress, Airbase, or Naval Base. Otherwise they must be transported. If adjacent to a foreign city, use the Do command (D) for Commerce functions.

‚û§ Belongs to Cargo unit class.

  ‚Ä¢ Pays 15% penalty (3 shields) for recycling production into Units and Buildings.
  ‚Ä¢ Can't Fortify.
  ‚Ä¢ Can be carried by any Commerce Unit, and Galleons.

‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't prevent enemy cities from working the tile it's on.

Freight

Cost: 25 shields
Upkeep: 0
Moves: 1
Vision: 1.41 tiles
Attack: 0
Defense: 0
Firepower: 1
Hitpoints: 1
Obsolete by: None
Freight brings benefits of organized efficiency. Like all Commerce units, it can Help Build Wonders, and Establish Trade Route. Unlike other Commerce units, it can Disband to Recycle Production with no net loss in shields. This gives Freight a variety of industrial uses. Similar to Infantry, Freight can use extra build slots a city may have.

By itself, Freight is only able to move to tiles with loading infrastructure: Cities, Railroads, Quays, Fortresses, Airbases, and Naval Bases. To be transported, it must be carried as cargo. If adjacent to a foreign city, use the D key to do Commerce functions.

üîπ Multislot: can use additional city build slots.

  ‚Ä¢ Pays no penalty for recycling production into Units, Buildings, or Wonders.
  ‚Ä¢ Can't Fortify.
  ‚Ä¢ Can be carried by Train, Truck, Cargo Ship, Transport, Airplane.
‚û§ RESTRICTED by Zones of Control.
‚û§ Imposes NO Zone of Control.
  ‚Ä¢ Doesn't prevent enemy cities from working the tile it's on.

This unit can fix unlucky starts, but has very high upkeep.

This unit can dig wells to create irrigation sources. It will cost its home city -2 Food -2 Prod. This unit WILL NOT WORK:
‚Ä¢ Outside your borders,
‚Ä¢ On Mountains,
‚Ä¢ After Alphabet or Pottery,
‚Ä¢ After any player discovers Writing,
‚Ä¢ After it reaches an age of 10 turns.

Magnum Turret

Cost: 160 shields
Upkeep: 1 Shield
Moves: 0
Vision: 2.00 tiles
Attack: 10
Defense: 7
Firepower: 3
Hitpoints: 40
Obsolete by: None
On rare occasions in history, nations constructed monumental turret guns. Cost-benefit is debatable among military theorists due to scale, cost, and immobility. The Magnum Turret stays where it‚Äôs built. You may build only one.

Housed in armored defenses, the Magnum Turret deters attackers and nearby enemy encampments. It may attack or bombard ocean tiles.

If it has moves left, the Magnum Turret can do 7 rounds of Bombardment up to 2 tiles distant upon five units, with two possible fatalities. When special attacked from range, it can retaliate with the same type of Bombardment.

VIGILÔºöthe Vigil order instructs the Magnum Turret to auto-Bombard adjacent military units if they have better attack odds.

‚û§ Belongs to LandImmobile unit class, Ballistic sub-class.
  ‚Ä¢ VIGIL: can be given the Vigil order to auto-Bombard adjacent military units.
  ‚Ä¢ Cannot move.
  ‚Ä¢ Cannot airlift.
  ‚Ä¢ Cannot be transported.
  ‚Ä¢ Gets a 50% defensive bonus while in cities.
  ‚Ä¢ NOT slowed while damaged.
‚û§ Unable to attack air units.
‚û§ Each player may only have one of this type of unit.
‚û§ Can safely conduct Bombard Attack.
    ‚Ä¢ Can do the action multiple times per turn.
    ‚Ä¢ Has a range of 2 tiles.
    ‚Ä¢ Gives 7 free rounds of combat against up to 5 units in an enemy stack.
    ‚Ä¢ Uses 1 movement point.
    ‚Ä¢ A maximum of 2 units can be killed.
    ‚Ä¢ Can be done to Ocean tiles.
    ‚Ä¢ Can be done to Cities, Forts, Airbases, Fortresses, Naval Bases, Castles, and Bunkers.
‚û§ Has Special Defense against Special Attacks / Ranged Attacks.
